channel.title: Ruby or Python?
channel.description:
I can't decide which Programming Language I should learn, either Ruby or Python?
Which do you think is most simplistic and easy to learn?

item.title: Ruby or Python?

item.description:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:18, topic:432089”][quote author=t4 link=topic=534798.msg3910275#msg3910275 date=1328654046]

crudentials? :s
on a positive note: props on using jython and props for using it on something that’s actually good to use it on!

Should of been credentials was making a quick example as I would never use a script for something as basic as that lol.

Yeh, python/jython is extremely useful. People just tend to be stuck in the mindset that since most sources are written in Java, that is the only way to go for everything.

unless of course you give two fucks about runtime benchmarks…
[/quote]

Ladies, have you heard the good news that is the scripting language called Lua?[/quote]

j# is where it is at :hurr:

item.title: Ruby or Python?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Pure Slay, post:11, topic:432089”][quote author=sinisoul link=topic=534798.msg3910122#msg3910122 date=1328640084]
I just enjoy Ruby more because of the syntax. It flows out to be more like writing instead of writing brain fuck. The scoping in Ruby I find to be convenient compared to other scripting languages I know such as Lua. Back to the syntax piece, writing code in Ruby is very easy but makes you feel some uncertainty because there are so many ways to get the sane result syntax wise. It covers a wide variety of styles and I really can’t say you are doing it wrong unless its bloated. Needless to say I don’t have an opinion on python because I haven’t used it much. I enjoyed it when I did use it but my opinion would be futile as compared to the opinion of Emily or t4.

You win either way. Also matters on the project.
[/quote]

I just personally like the way python flows. This is just an example snippet but it is just so much easier and faster to write than java.

21e68vp.png902×576

It is personally why I use python scripts for all login related scripts.

Edit:
or for a longer example:

[CODE]
import org.arsenal.net.io.InputStream as stream
import org.arsenal.net.io.Session as session
import org.arsenal.rscache.Cache as cache
import org.arsenal.world.model.player.Player as player
import org.arsenal.util.Misc as misc
import org.arsenal.util.SerializableFilesManager as fileManager
import logging

class Login562:

def decode(stream):
    session.setDecoder(-1)
    packetId = stream.readUnsignedByte()
    logging.info("Packet Id"+packetId)
    if packetId == 16 or packetId == 18 or packetId == 19:
        decodeWorldLogin(stream)
    else: 
        logging.info("PacketId: "+packetId)
        session.getChannel().close()
    
def decodeWorldLogin(stream):
    packetSize = stream.readUnsignedByte()
    if packetSize != stream.getRemaining():
        session.getChannel().close()
        return
    if stream.readInt() != 562:
        logging.info("Invalid revision trying to connect")
        return
    stream.readByte()
    displayMode = stream.readUnsignedShort()
    screenWidth = stream.readUnsignedShort()
    screenHeight = stream.readUnsignedShort()
    for i in range(0, 24):
        stream.readInt()
    stream.readString()
    stream.readInt()
    stream.readInt()
    stream.readShort()
    for i in range(0, 29):
        if cache.getCacheFileManagers()[i] == null:
            crc = 0
        else:
            crc = cache.getCacheFileManagers()[i].getInformation().getInformationContainer().getCrc()
        if crc != stream.readInt():
            logging.info("Invalid Crc Keys")    
    if stream.readUnsignedByte() != 10:
        logging.info("Invalid rsa header")
        return
    for i in range(0, 4):
        stream.readInt()
    playerLongName = stream.readLong()
    password = stream.readString()
    username = misc.formatPlayerNameForProtocol(misc.longToString(playerLongName))
    if fileManager.containsPlayer(username):
        player = player(password)
    else:
        player = fileManager.loadPlayer(username)
        if player == null:
            return
    player.init(session, username, displayMode, screenWidth, screenHeight)
    session.setDecoder(3, player)
    session.setEncoder(2, player)
    player.start()

[/CODE][/quote]
crudentials? :s

on a positive note: props on using jython and props for using it on something that’s actually good to use it on!

Read full topic

item.title: Ruby or Python?
item.dc:creator: @Pure_Slay Pure Slay
item.description:
@Pure_Slay wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:9, topic:432089”]I just enjoy Ruby more because of the syntax. It flows out to be more like writing instead of writing brain fuck. The scoping in Ruby I find to be convenient compared to other scripting languages I know such as Lua. Back to the syntax piece, writing code in Ruby is very easy but makes you feel some uncertainty because there are so many ways to get the sane result syntax wise. It covers a wide variety of styles and I really can’t say you are doing it wrong unless its bloated. Needless to say I don’t have an opinion on python because I haven’t used it much. I enjoyed it when I did use it but my opinion would be futile as compared to the opinion of Emily or t4.

You win either way. Also matters on the project.[/quote]

I just personally like the way python flows. This is just an example snippet but it is just so much easier and faster to write than java.

21e68vp.png902×576

It is personally why I use python scripts for all login related scripts.

Edit:
or for a longer example:

import org.arsenal.net.io.InputStream as stream
import org.arsenal.net.io.Session as session
import org.arsenal.rscache.Cache as cache
import org.arsenal.world.model.player.Player as player
import org.arsenal.util.Misc as misc
import org.arsenal.util.SerializableFilesManager as fileManager
import logging

class Login562:
    
    def decode(stream):
        session.setDecoder(-1)
        packetId = stream.readUnsignedByte()
        logging.info("Packet Id"+packetId)
        if packetId == 16 or packetId == 18 or packetId == 19:
            decodeWorldLogin(stream)
        else: 
            logging.info("PacketId: "+packetId)
            session.getChannel().close()
        
    def decodeWorldLogin(stream):
        packetSize = stream.readUnsignedByte()
        if packetSize != stream.getRemaining():
            session.getChannel().close()
            return
        if stream.readInt() != 562:
            logging.info("Invalid revision trying to connect")
            return
        stream.readByte()
        displayMode = stream.readUnsignedShort()
        screenWidth = stream.readUnsignedShort()
        screenHeight = stream.readUnsignedShort()
        for i in range(0, 24):
            stream.readInt()
        stream.readString()
        stream.readInt()
        stream.readInt()
        stream.readShort()
        for i in range(0, 29):
            if cache.getCacheFileManagers()[i] == null:
                crc = 0
            else:
                crc = cache.getCacheFileManagers()[i].getInformation().getInformationContainer().getCrc()
            if crc != stream.readInt():
                logging.info("Invalid Crc Keys")    
        if stream.readUnsignedByte() != 10:
            logging.info("Invalid rsa header")
            return
        for i in range(0, 4):
            stream.readInt()
        playerLongName = stream.readLong()
        password = stream.readString()
        username = misc.formatPlayerNameForProtocol(misc.longToString(playerLongName))
        if fileManager.containsPlayer(username):
            player = player(password)
        else:
            player = fileManager.loadPlayer(username)
            if player == null:
                return
        player.init(session, username, displayMode, screenWidth, screenHeight)
        session.setDecoder(3, player)
        session.setEncoder(2, player)
        player.start()

item.title: Ruby or Python?
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

I just enjoy Ruby more because of the syntax. It flows out to be more like writing instead of writing brain fuck. The scoping in Ruby I find to be convenient compared to other scripting languages I know such as Lua. Back to the syntax piece, writing code in Ruby is very easy but makes you feel some uncertainty because there are so many ways to get the sane result syntax wise. It covers a wide variety of styles and I really can’t say you are doing it wrong unless its bloated. Needless to say I don’t have an opinion on python because I haven’t used it much. I enjoyed it when I did use it but my opinion would be futile as compared to the opinion of Emily or t4.

You win either way. Also matters on the project.

Read full topic

item.title: Ruby or Python?
item.dc:creator: @Pure_Slay Pure Slay
item.description:
@Pure_Slay wrote:

It all depends on your use and preference. I use python for scripting, were as Sini uses ruby. Does it make either of us wrong using a different language? No, but we are both using it for our own personal concepts.

For ‘easiness’ of learning, I would say neither is an easy language to learn. All programming languages require some sort of intellect and drive for you to learn. Someone may learn python x100 faster than they learn ruby, where as someone else could be completely flipped. Try one and see if it interests you, if you can’t seem to get the hang of it, try the other. Luckily there are lots of documentation and other optional scripting languages if you can’t figure one out completely.

Read full topic
